Award.AwardTitle: Multiscale Modeling of Aerosol Indirect Effects on Decadal Timescales
Award.AbstractNarration:
Aerosol effects on clouds operate at spatial scales of short-lived cloud updrafts (typically 100 m- 100 km), yet exert a global effect on climate over multiple decades. The multiscale nature of these indirect effects on the planetary energy balance presents particular challenges to climate modeling, which has led to large uncertainties in estimates of indirect effects. The most difficult types of aerosol indirect effects to quantify are those for which the aerosol sources are controlled by complex interactions of ecosystems with climate, such as the aerosol emissions from ocean phytoplankton and from wildfires in forests. This project addresses these challenges through a combination of advanced parameterizations, explicit modeling, and observations with a multi-institutional,multi-disciplinary team of experts. Advanced parameterizations of aerosol effects on stratocumulus, shallow cumulus and deep cumulus clouds that have been or are being developed under separate funding will be brought together into a common framework for multidecadal simulations with coupling to the ocean. The simulations with and without aerosols will be examined to determine the influence of aerosol indirect effects on decadal climate variability. This evaluation will be accomplished by relating climate-scale changes in oceanic and atmospheric conditions over the Pacific to the sensitivities of regional ocean-atmosphere interactions to aerosols along the west coast of North America and consequent atmospheric conditions over the entire U.S.

The broader educational impacts of the research will be realized through: (1) Promotion of teaching, training and learning through development and piloting of an informal science education program targeting an underserved audience; (2) Broadened participation of underrepresented groups--in this case, retired and elderly people--in scientific learning; (3) Enhancement of infrastructure for teaching through partnerships with an established educational organization; (4) Broad dissemination of results through presentations, peer-reviewed publications and via the web; and (5) Societal benefits in terms of improved understanding of climate science and the related ethical issues. In addition to outreach activities, there will be at least three graduate students who will each receive three years of training in coupled Earth system modeling as part of this project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Aerosol effects on clouds operate at spatial scales of short-lived cloud updrafts (typically 100 m to 100 km), yet exert a global effect on climate over multiple decades. The multiscale nature of these indirect effects on the planetary energy balance presents particular challenges to climate modeling, which has led to large uncertainties in estimates of indirect effects.  The most difficult types of aerosol indirect effects to quantify are those for which the aerosol sources are controlled by complex interactions of ecosystems with climate, such as the aerosol emissions from ocean phytoplankton and from wildfires in forests.  This project addressed these challenges through a combination of advanced parameterizations, explicit modeling, and observations with a multi-institutional, multi-disciplinary team of experts. Advanced parameterizations of aerosol effects on stratocumulus, shallow cumulus and deep cumulus clouds that were developed under separate funding were brought together into a common framework for multidecadal simulations with coupling to the ocean. The simulations with and without aerosols were examined to determine the influence of aerosol indirect effects on decadal climate variability. This evaluation was completed by relating climate-scale changes in oceanic and atmospheric conditions over the Pacific to the sensitivities of regional ocean-atmosphere interactions to aerosols along the west coast of North America and consequent atmospheric conditions over the entire U.S.

The primary purpose of this project is to explore the role of aerosol effects on decadal variability of the climate through a variety of mechanisms involving emissions from the surface and subsequent direct and indirect effects on the planetary energy balance. The goals of this EaSM Type 2 project were

1) Model evaluation of cloud parameterizations,

2) Quantify anthropogenic aerosol effects on shallow and deep convective as well as stratiform clouds, and

3) Quantify the influence of aerosol indirect effects on decadal variability.

Model evaluation of cloud parameterizations was achieved by incorporating new descriptions of cloud processes into a community climate model and comparing the resulting model simulations with other models, as reported by Song et al. (2012) and Storer et al. (2015). Anthropogenic aerosol effects on shallow and deep convective as well as stratiform clouds were quantified by developing new ways to constrain model uncertainties (with “nudging”), evaluating the daily cycles of clouds, and relating the modeled meteorological responses to impacts on urban pollution, as reported by Kooperman et al. (2012; 2014) and Yang et al. (2017).  The influence of aerosol indirect effects on decadal variability was quantified by assessing the impacts and feedbacks of sea spray, dust, and marine biogenic sulfur aerosol particles on temperature, clouds, and precipitation using simulations of 150 years or more and available observational records, as reported by Yang et al. (2016a,b,c), Lou et al. (2016), Xu et al. (2015; 2016), De Florio et al. (2013; 2014), and Putrasahan et al. (2013a,b).

The broader educational impacts of the research were completed by: (1) Promotion of teaching, training and learning through development and piloting of an informal science education program targeting an underserved audience; (2) Broadened participation of underrepresented groups – in this case, retired and elderly people – in scientific learning; (3) Enhancement of infrastructure for teaching through partnerships with an established educational organization; (4) Broad dissemination of results through presentations, peer-reviewed publications and via the web; and (5) Societal benefits in terms of improved understanding of climate science and the related ethical issues. In addition to outreach activities, there were substantial training opportunities in coupled Earth system modeling as part of this project: three graduate students together received more than 5 years of training, seven postdocs received a total of 7 years of training, and two undergraduate students received 4 months of training. In addition, two young scientists were supported.
